description: 1812, possibly from dialectal German Jokel, diminutive of Jakob, cf. Yankee (“little John”) and jacquerie (“peasant uprising”). Alternatively, from dialectal English yokel (“woodpecker”).

entries.meaning: (derogatory) A person from or living in the countryside, viewed as being unsophisticated and/or naive.
examples: Synonyms: boor, bumpkin, country bumpkin, joskin, hillbilly, hick, peasant, provincial, rube, rustic, yahoo
They love the scenery near their summer home, but have no desire to mix with the local yokels.
